overview_of_class:
The human brain has properties that are unique in the animal kingdom, and is widely assumed to
underlie our species' unusual level of sociality, ability for complex culture, and distinctive
achievements in areas like technological innovation and the arts. Recent scientific advances are
allowing the brain's function to be probed through means of non-invasive imaging, which has
led to an explosion of neuroscientific research and important developments in our understanding
of how our brains work. Yet the intense "neuro-enthusiasm" this has sparked has also
contributed to new forms of biological reductionism and over-simplified notions of the brain's
role in...well, nearly every aspect of human experience. In this wide-ranging seminar we will
explore the human brain from a range of complementary perspectives, with an overarching
agenda of exploring the social and cultural ecology of mind and brain. One important area of
inquiry will therefore include a consideration of development and the mechanisms of neuronal
plasticity that link experiences with brain and mind through processes of learning, skill
development, and memory. The theme of embodiment will cross-cut many of the course
discussions, and underscore the intimate connections between the brain and body that lead to
reciprocal influences among brain, experience, and behavior. Because of the brain's role in
regulating the body's many biological systems, neuronal plasticity also has effects that link our
histories and experiences, such as stress or opportunity, to altered biological regulation, and thus
health. Topics explored will include: the brain in society; evolution of the social brain; neural
plasticity and development; embodiment; emotion and reason in the brain; sex, gender, race,
racism and the brain; and cultural neuroscience and the encultured brain.
